entry.title: Re: Enhance Abap CDS View I_EquipmentData
entry.content:
Hi,

long time ago.

First, do not enhance e.g. cds view i_equipmentdata directly, it will work but this will cause trouble during the next update.  

I created a CDS view "ZX_IEquipmentData" type "extension view".

...
extend view I_EquipmentData with ZX_IEquipmentData

association [0..1] to egers as _Egers on $projection.equipment = _Egers.equipment
{
_Egers.neededfield1,
_Egers.neededfield2 as AliasNeededfield2,
case  <>
else
<>
end as as AliasNeededfieldx
}

Then you can use the cds view as an odp datasource in BW and drop the 0EQUIPMENT_ATTR. 

Quite sure there are better approaches, but everybody can see they are not shared by the cool experts.

Br.,

Telli

entry.title: The Next Frontier in SAP Finance: AI-Driven Continuous Close and Predictive Compliance
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs finance landscape, CFOs and finance leaders are under constant pressure to deliver faster insights, ensure regulatory compliance, and optimize global operations. Traditional month-end close cycles are no longer sufficient in an era where investors, auditors, and boards expect real-time transparency.

This is where SAP S/4HANA Finance combined with Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) is reshaping the game.

From Periodic Close to Continuous Close

The Universal Journal (ACDOCA) and SAP Central Finance laid the foundation for harmonized reporting across multiple entities. Now, AI extends this further by automating:

  • Journal entry validation with anomaly detection, reducing manual interventions.

  • Predictive accruals and provisions, ensuring accuracy before close.

  • Intercompany reconciliation across 50+ ERP landscapes in near real-time.

Instead of ‚Äúwaiting for month-end,‚Äù finance leaders can run predictive financial statements on-demand.

AI-Powered Predictive Compliance

Compliance frameworks such as SOX, IFRS 17, and ESG reporting require more than accuracy ‚Äì they demand foresight. SAP‚Äôs integration of AI with Group Reporting and Governance, Risk & Compliance (GRC) allows:

  • Continuous monitoring of transactions against regulatory benchmarks.

  • Automated generation of IFRS-compliant disclosures.

  • Early detection of compliance risks before audits.

This shift transforms compliance from a reactive exercise to a strategic advantage.

Real-World Applications

Forward-thinking enterprises are already seeing results:

  • A global energy company leveraged SAP Cash Application with AI to reduce unapplied cash by 70%.

  • A multinational FMCG firm integrated predictive accounting into S/4HANA, reducing close cycles from 5 days to 1 day.

  • Several Fortune 500 firms are piloting AI-driven ESG reporting inside SAP Finance, preparing for the SEC‚Äôs new climate disclosure rules.

Why This Matters for Finance Leaders

Finance is no longer about reporting the past ‚Äì it‚Äôs about shaping the future. CFOs who harness AI-enabled SAP Finance are positioning themselves as:

  • Strategic advisors to the board.

  • Guardians of compliance and trust in a digital world.

  • Drivers of enterprise value creation through predictive insights.

Looking Ahead

The convergence of SAP S/4HANA Finance, AI/ML, and real-time compliance signals a new era: the AI-Driven Continuous Close. This isn‚Äôt just an IT upgrade ‚Äì it‚Äôs a paradigm shift in financial leadership.

Finance professionals who embrace this shift today will be tomorrow‚Äôs industry trailblazers.

@sureshsadhuSAP #sureshsadhuSAP

 

 

#sureshsadhu #sap #USA #FICO

entry.title: Re: An application error occurred. Please try again later...
entry.content:
Hi @Anu32 

Hope you are doing well.

Community would not be the best place for handling Server Log Errors. When encountering server log errors such as this one, the optimal approach is to create a support ticket with SAP from your LAUNCHPAD. Please follow these steps for a smooth and efficient resolution process: 

Necessary Details for Support Ticket

  • System ID: Provide the identification for your system.  Please ensure the system given in the ticket is the one where the issue occurs.
  • Support Access: Ensure SAP support has the necessary access to assist you. 2088892 - How to Grant Support Access to SAP SuccessFactors Support Staff - SAP for Me
  • Error Details: Include a detailed description of the error message. "An application error occurred. Please try again later, or notify support (with the error information of errorID=31b52631-a796-4020-abf0-04d9d776d870, timestamp=2025-09-04T09:48:16.751+0000, and the version information from the current screen) if the issue keeps occurring." include an image if possible.
  • Steps to Replicate: Outline the steps to reproduce the error.

Additional Information

Guidance: Refer to the relevant article for comprehensive details on the information required. 2748769 - Best Practices For Opening and Updating SuccessFactors Support Cases - SAP for Me

Components: Make sure to create the ticket under the correct component, such as:

  • Onboarding
  • Employee Central
  • Etc.

By including these details, you will enable SAP support to address your issue more effectively.

I hope this helps.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP Incentive Management for Real-time Incentive calculation
entry.content:
Integrating SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management creates a powerful solution for real-time incentive calculation and sales performance optimization. Here's a breakdown of how this integration works and the benefits it offers:

Integration Overview

The mashup between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management enables sales teams to:

  • View real-time incentive data directly within the Sales Cloud interface.
  • Access a unified dashboard showing opportunities, leads, commissions, and payouts.
  • Receive instant updates as deals progress, with incentive data refreshed in real time.
  • Gain actionable insights into how performance affects earnings and what actions can maximize incentives.

Key Benefits

  1. Real-Time Insights & Motivation

    • Sales reps can see their commissions and performance metrics instantly.
    • Features like commission estimates, leaderboards, and performance dashboards help boost motivation.

  2. Streamlined Dispute Resolution

    • One-click traceability allows quick resolution of compensation inquiries.
    • Reduces administrative overhead and keeps reps focused on selling.

  3. Optimized Incentive Plans

    • Use AI-driven recommendations to refine compensation strategies.
    • Identify opportunities for bonuses or accelerators to maximize ROI.

  4. Flexible Plan Design

    • Easily model and test complex incentive plans using drag-and-drop tools.
    • Roll out new promotions without heavy IT involvement

Implementation Highlights

  • Once integrated, users can navigate to Sales History ‚Üí Opportunities in SAP Sales Cloud V2.
  • A new dashboard section appears showing incentives and payments.
  • The mashup is enabled via standard configuration steps provided by SAP.

Integration Flow Description

  1. SAP Sales Cloud V2

    • Opportunity is created and assigned to a Opportunity Owner (Sales Employee).
    • Opportunity data includes total revenue,opporuntiy date, product, and stage.

  2. Employee Sync

    • The Employee in Sales Cloud is synced with SuccessFactors via master data integration.
    • Employee is linked to a Position in Incentive Manager.

  3. SuccessFactors Incentive Management

    • The Position is mapped to an Incentive Plan.
    • Incentive Plan defines rules, rule elements including quotas, accelerators, and payout logic.

  4. Real-Time Calculation

    • As the Opportunity progresses, incentive calculations are triggered.
    • Sales reps can view estimated commissions, performance dashboards, and leaderboards directly in Sales Cloud.

  5. Feedback Loop

    • Incentive results are sent back to Sales Cloud for visibility.
    • Managers can adjust plans or resolve disputes using traceable data.

entry.title: Re: CDS View for Project Budet,Actual And Commitment in S...
entry.content:
Hello @Jagdish1 

You don‚Äôt need custom enhancements; simply use Project Availability Control (AVC). When assigning a WBS in PR/PO, AVC compares the consumable budget with commitments and actuals, and can either warn or block you to save. Just activate and assign an AVC profile to your projects. For tolerances and messages. Check SAP Learning-Understanding Availability Control and SAP Help Portal-Maintain Budget Availability Control Profile for Projects

Regarding CDS views: no single released CDS provides combined data for budget, commitment, and actual. Instead, use available analytics such as the Budget and Commitment /Actual Line Item Analyser, or construct a composite view from budget (planning/budget views), commitments, and Journal Entry Item ACDOCA actuals. SAP Help Portal-Budget and Commitment/Actual Line Item Analyzer SAP Community

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Embedding Native Android Crypto in SSAM: A QR-Code Security Story
entry.content:
Embedding Native AES-256 Encryption in SSAM with NativeScript

Introduction

As mobile developers working on SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM), we often encounter scenarios where field technicians must collaborate closely to complete maintenance work. One of the challenges in these environments is ensuring that cooperation is documented, validated, and secure‚Äîespecially when multiple technicians interact with the same work order.

Recently, we explored a QR-Code-based workflow that makes collaboration and double-checks simple, fast, and reliable. The idea is straightforward:

  • User1 first generates a QR-Code that includes their personnel ID, a validity window (start/end date), and a stamp of their authorized scenarios. At this stage, no choice is made between cooperation or double-check ‚Äî the QR-Code simply encodes what User1 is permitted to do.
  • Later, when User2 is performing a task in the field, they select whether the activity is a cooperation or a double-check inside SSAM on their Android or iOS phone or tablet. User2 then scans User1‚Äôs QR-Code.
  • If the scan occurs within the validity window and User1 is authorized for the chosen scenario, SSAM creates a confirmation in the SAP system tied to User1, including any comments embedded in the QR-Code. If the QR-Code is expired or the selected scenario is not authorized for User1, SSAM immediately returns an error message explaining the issue (for example: ‚ÄúQR-Code expired‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnauthorized scenario‚Äù).

This ensures that every confirmation is validated against both time and authorization, keeping the workflow secure, auditable, and resistant to tampering.

This is a perfect example of a workflow that is both human-friendly and security-critical. The data in the QR-Code must be protected from tampering or unauthorized reading, because it affects operational records and accountability.

Why Secure QR-Codes Matter

In enterprise field operations:

  • Unauthorized edits can create compliance and audit issues. For example, if someone were able to forge a QR-Code saying a work order was double-checked when it wasn‚Äôt, it could compromise safety and regulatory compliance.
  • Sensitive data exposure could reveal internal workflows or personnel assignments to outside parties. Even small leaks can have serious implications in regulated industries.
  • Trust between technicians depends on verifiable records. QR-Codes that are cryptographically secured ensure that cooperation and double-check events can be audited confidently.

This means the QR-Code must not only be readable by the app but also tamper-proof. AES-256 encryption provides that guarantee when implemented correctly.

The Magic of Native Code in NativeScript

NativeScript is a cross-platform framework that allows JavaScript developers to call native APIs directly on iOS and Android. This capability is more than just a performance trick‚Äîit opens the door to:

  • Using platform-proven cryptography directly, like javax.crypto on Android or CommonCrypto on iOS.
  • Avoiding complex JavaScript crypto implementations that are slower and error-prone.
  • Accessing system-level features without writing a full native module.

In SSAM, this is particularly powerful because:

  • Extensions often need high-performance logic for encryption, image processing, or offline data manipulation.
  • We can write one JavaScript method that bridges into Android and iOS, keeping the business logic shared but the platform calls native.
  • It keeps the app lightweight, avoids large third-party libraries, and gives us full control over cryptography and encoding.

Essentially, NativeScript allows us to write JavaScript that feels like native code, with all the power, security, and speed of the underlying platform.

üëâIn this post, we‚Äôll focus on the Android implementation of AES-256 encryption. In a future blog, we‚Äôll show the iOS version side-by-side, demonstrating how both can live under the same JavaScript class.

Illustrative AES-256 Android Library

To demonstrate this, we built a small, self-contained library that performs AES-256-CBC encryption and decryption using native Android APIs. This is not a production-ready library, but it clearly shows how you can leverage native crypto safely in a NativeScript environment.

import logger from '../Log/Logger';

export default class NativeCryptoLibraryAndroid {

    /**
     * Derive a 32-byte AES key from a password.
     * Uses SHA-256 to normalize any password length into a proper AES key size.
     */
    static generateKeyFromPassword(password) {
        const passwordBytes = new java.lang.String(password).getBytes('UTF-8');
        const md = java.security.MessageDigest.getInstance('SHA-256');
        return md.digest(passwordBytes); // returns a Java byte[]
    }

    /**
     * Convert a hex string into a Java byte array.
     * Needed for IV handling, since IVs are often stored/transmitted as hex.
     */
    static hexToBytes(hex) {
        const bytes = Array.create('byte', hex.length / 2);
        for (let i = 0; i < hex.length; i += 2) {
            bytes[i / 2] = java.lang.Byte.parseByte(hex.substr(i, 2), 16);
        }
        return bytes;
    }

    /**
     * Encrypt plaintext using AES-256-CBC.
     * - Derives key from password
     * - Uses provided IV (or default if none supplied)
     * - Returns Base64 so it can be safely embedded in a QR-Code
     */
    static encrypt(plainText, password, ivHex = '7361705F6369706865725F696E69745F') {
        try {
            const keyBytes = this.generateKeyFromPassword(password);
            const secretKey = new javax.crypto.spec.SecretKeySpec(keyBytes, 'AES');

            const ivBytes = this.hexToBytes(ivHex);
            const ivSpec = new javax.crypto.spec.IvParameterSpec(ivBytes);

            const cipher = javax.crypto.Cipher.getInstance('AES/CBC/PKCS5Padding');
            cipher.init(javax.crypto.Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, secretKey, ivSpec);

            const plainTextBytes = new java.lang.String(plainText).getBytes('UTF-8');
            const cipherTextBytes = cipher.doFinal(plainTextBytes);

            // Prepend IV to ciphertext so it can be reused during decryption
            const combined = new java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream();
            combined.write(ivBytes);
            combined.write(cipherTextBytes);

            // Base64 encode for QR-Code embedding
            return String(java.util.Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString(combined.toByteArray()));
        } catch (e) {
            logger.error('Crypto', 'encrypt error: ' + e.message);
            return null;
        }
    }

    /**
     * Decrypt Base64 ciphertext back into UTF-8 string.
     * Assumes IV is stored in the first 16 bytes of the encrypted payload.
     */
    static decrypt(encryptedBase64, password) {
        try {
            const keyBytes = this.generateKeyFromPassword(password);
            const secretKey = new javax.crypto.spec.SecretKeySpec(keyBytes, 'AES');

            const encryptedBytes = java.util.Base64.getDecoder().decode(encryptedBase64);

            // Extract IV (first 16 bytes) and ciphertext (remaining bytes)
            const ivBytes = java.util.Arrays.copyOfRange(encryptedBytes, 0, 16);
            const cipherTextBytes = java.util.Arrays.copyOfRange(encryptedBytes, 16, encryptedBytes.length);

            const cipher = javax.crypto.Cipher.getInstance('AES/CBC/PKCS5Padding');
            const ivSpec = new javax.crypto.spec.IvParameterSpec(ivBytes);
            cipher.init(javax.crypto.Cipher.DECRYPT_MODE, secretKey, ivSpec);

            const decryptedBytes = cipher.doFinal(cipherTextBytes);
            return new java.lang.String(decryptedBytes, 'UTF-8').toString();
        } catch (e) {
            logger.error('Crypto', 'decrypt error: ' + e.message);
            return null;
        }
    }
}

Testing the Library

Here‚Äôs a simple test wrapper that demonstrates end-to-end encryption and decryption:

import NativeCryptoLibraryAndroid from './NativeCryptoLibraryAndroid';

export default function AndroidCryptoTest() {
    const password = 'SecretPass123!';
    const message = 'Assistance + √úberpr√ºfung f√ºr Double-Check ‚úÖ';

    console.log('Original Payload: ' + message);

    // Encrypt payload for QR-Code embedding
    const encrypted = NativeCryptoLibraryAndroid.encrypt(message, password);
    console.log('Encrypted QR Payload: ' + encrypted);

    // Decrypt back after scanning
    const decrypted = NativeCryptoLibraryAndroid.decrypt(encrypted, password);
    console.log('Decrypted Payload: ' + decrypted);

    if (message === decrypted) {
        console.log('‚úÖ Encryption/Decryption successful!');
    } else {
        console.warn('‚ö†Ô∏è Decrypted payload does not match original!');
    }
}

‚úÖThis test highlights:
- Native AES-256 encryption
- Full Unicode support (German umlauts, emojis, checkmarks)
- Round-trip safety: plaintext ‚Üí encrypted QR-Code ‚Üí decrypted confirmation

Why Hex and Base64 Matter

When working with global enterprise data:

  • Hex encoding ensures byte arrays (like SHA-256 hashes or IVs) can be safely represented as strings.
  • Base64 encoding allows binary ciphertext to be safely embedded in QR-Codes, which are strictly text-based.

Without proper encoding, QR-Codes could corrupt Unicode characters or fail to round-trip correctly across platforms.

Lessons Learned

  1. Security comes first: Encrypting QR-Code payloads prevents forgery and protects sensitive workflow data.
  2. Native beats JS for crypto: Using Android/iOS APIs ensures better performance, correctness, and maintainability.
  3. Cross-platform consistency: With careful IV, encoding, and padding handling, a QR-Code generated on one OS can be read on another.
  4. Unicode matters: Base64 ensures comments in any language‚ÄîGerman, Chinese, Arabic, emojis‚Äîremain intact.
  5. NativeScript‚Äôs power: The ability to call native APIs directly is a huge advantage for any performance- or security-critical logic.

Closing Thoughts

This QR-Code feature is not just a convenience; it‚Äôs about secure collaboration in the field. By leveraging native cryptography in a NativeScript-based SSAM extension, we can deliver a solution that is fast, secure, and cross-platform, while keeping the JavaScript layer simple and readable.

The broader lesson? When facing performance-critical or sensitive operations, let native code do the heavy lifting. NativeScript gives us a unique bridge to do exactly that, blending the simplicity of JavaScript with the power of the underlying platform.

And stay tuned‚Äîour next blog will show the iOS implementation, so you can see the complete cross-platform picture in action.

The reason why you are unable to raise request „ÄåSet up„ÄÄHyperscaler VPN Connection„Äçis because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the „ÄåSet up„ÄÄHyperscaler VPN Connection„Äçtemplate, an S-user must be authorized to Create Billable Service Requests at the customer number level.

Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Typically, you would need to reach out to your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization reassigned.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: Integrated Financial Planning OPEX Cost Rates Data Ac...
entry.content:
@hartmut_koernerthank you for your prompt responses. As per the standard code, if no allocation account exists, it returns a NULL value. // Find out, if valid default allocation account exists

// Aggregate total amount on default account "#"

DATA([d/Measures] = #M1, [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT] = "#", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "C") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "D")

// Copy total amount to default allocation account

DATA([d/Measures] = #M2, [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT] = [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT].[p/ALLOCATION_ACCOUNT]) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = #M1) @Default_Alloc_Account_Exists = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = #M2) * 0 + 1

// Avoid Null values

@Default_Alloc_Account_Exists = @Default_Alloc_Account_Exists + 0

 

 

Right? And if that‚Äôs the case, then how can this RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = #IS_ALLOC_ACCOUNT_VALID) = 0  ever be equal to zero?
Because if it equals zero, the logic will enter the loop and check other conditions. Inside the loop, it would then hit the second condition:

 

 
ELSEIF @Default_Alloc_Account_Exists = 0 THEN

But I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs correct. Based on the earlier logic, the value should be NULL if no allocation account exists. So ideally, this entire part of the code shouldn‚Äôt even run.

 

// If allocation account is invalid... 
IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = #IS_ALLOC_ACCOUNT_VALID) = 0 THEN
// ...but default allocation account exists 
IF @Default_Alloc_Account_Exists > 0 THEN
// Allocate to default allocation account (allocation account of "#" account): First create virtual credit record with switched sign on default allocation account 
DATA([d/Measures] = #TOTAL_AMT_ON_DEFAULT_ALLOC_ACCOUNT, [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT] = "#", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "D", [d/Date] = #T1)
= RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "D", [d/Date] = #T1)
// If no valid default allocation account exists, use original account
ELSEIF @Default_Alloc_Account_Exists = 0 THEN
// Create debit record on original account
DATA([d/Measures] = #TOTAL_AMT_ON_ORIGINAL_ACCOUNT, [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "D", [d/Date] = #T1)
= RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "AMOUNT", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "D", [d/Date] = #T1)
ENDIF
ENDIF

entry.title: Re: "Could Not Open App" Error in SAP Mobile Start Androi...
entry.content:
Hi @ItsMeGopi  

The issue you described is a common integration issue faced with SAP Mobile Start and SAP Build Work Zone standard edition when accessing apps via mobile versus desktop. Usually, it works on desktop but fails on mobile due to specific content configuration or authentication setup. To resolve the issue, I suggest you consider the following steps.

  1. Check Content Configuration of the Application you have deployed. Ensure that the app‚Äôs content configuration in SAP Build Work Zone includes the required semanticObject and action parameters. These configurations are essential for successful navigation on mobile devices using SAP Mobile Start, even if the app works fine on desktop browsers. They allow Mobile Start to resolve the navigation target correctly. After making these changes, refresh the HTML5 content in the SAP Build Work Zone Content-Channel-Manager.
  2. Then ensure to review your Authentication and Trust Settings. Make sure your BTP subaccount and Cloud Identity Service trust is set up as OpenID Connect, as required. Confirm that redirect URIs for OpenID Connect are properly configured for both desktop and mobile access. Sometimes, mobile apps require specific settings, such as default sites and correct domain mapping.
  3. Thereafter, ensure to update your Navigation Service Configuration. Note, the SAP Mobile Start app relies on correct Navigation Service parameters (semanticObject and action) for mobile navigation. If these are missing or misconfigured, the app tile will appear but cannot open.
  4. Finally, on your Android device, clear the cache or data of Mobile Start or reinstall the app. Sometimes cached credentials or outdated metadata impair app access after configuration changes.

Consult the following references for more information.

Setting Up the SAP Mobile Start Application

SAP Mobile Start fails to load App

I hope this provides the desired insights. Should you have further questions, do not hesitate to reach out.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Issue with Quota Display in Fiori 'My Leave Request' App When Available Balance is Exceeded
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I've identified a functional issue in the Fiori "My Leave Request" application regarding how the leave quota balance is displayed and updated. This problem provides incorrect information to the user during the submission process, leading to confusion and disruption in the leave approval workflow.

Detailed Problem Description:

On the app's main screen, there are three primary columns for managing the annual leave entitlement: Available, Used, and Planned.

The issue occurs when a user attempts to submit a leave request for a duration that is greater than their remaining available balance. In this scenario, instead of showing an immediate error message or preventing the submission, the application simply does not react. The values in the "Available" and "Planned" columns do not get updated, leading the user to incorrectly believe that their request can be submitted without a problem.

Practical Example:

To illustrate the issue, please consider the following scenario:

  • Employee's Initial Leave Entitlement: 25 hours
  • Daily Work Schedule: 8.5 hours
  1. First Request: The employee submits a leave request for one day (8.5 hours).
    • System Behavior (Correct): The Available balance decreases to 16.5 hours, and the Planned balance increases to 8.5 hours.
  2. Second Request: The employee submits another leave request for a different day (8.5 hours).
    • System Behavior (Correct): The Available balance is correctly reduced again to 8 hours, and the Planned balance increases to 17 hours.
  3. Third Request (Where the issue occurs): The employee now tries to submit a third leave request for another day (8.5 hours), while their remaining Available balance is only 8 hours.
    • Expected Behavior: The application should immediately display an error message, such as "Insufficient quota available," and prevent the user from proceeding.
    • Actual System Behavior (The Bug): The application shows no reaction. The Available balance remains at 8 hours, and no value is added to the Planned balance. The user, receiving no warning, proceeds to submit the request to their manager.

The backend logic is working correctly (the manager receives an error when trying to approve the invalid request), but the front-end experience is misleading.

Has anyone else encountered this issue? Any guidance on what might be causing this or a potential solution would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: How to print fixed asset cards in public cloudÔºü
entry.content:
Hello @jason_su 

Thank you for your question. Let me provide some more content.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition currently does not provide a dedicated app for printing fixed asset cards as a standard feature. The functionality available for asset management in the public cloud focuses on reports and analytics, not on generating or printing traditional asset inventory cards.

For fixed assets you can use apps such as Manage Fixed Assets for asset data management and reporting. Standard reports on fixed assets are accessible via Fiori but fixed asset card printouts as used in some countries for physical inventory or local compliance are not supported out-of-the-box in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Please note that some regional localizations may provide specialized reports but these are not globally available and usually limited to specific legal scope items.

However, there are alternatives and Workarounds you can consider in achieving your goal:

  • First is through custom report development. Here you can consult your SAP implementation partner to create a custom analytical report or tile to export fixed asset data in a printable format if your business/legal requirements demand printed asset cards.
  • Second is the SAP Output Management. You can manage your printing requirements via Output Management but asset cards are not included in the standard output forms for fixed assets.

The following reference links will provide further details.

Asset Accounting Overview

SAP Fiori app reference for asset management

I hope this provides the desired insights. Should you have further questions, do not hesitate to reach out.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to run SAP query in background and create a file in application server
entry.content:
For those who read this blog post, the ABAP code formatting used may impair the legibility, so here is the same code better formatted:

*Data Declaration.
DATA: c_lv_buf      TYPE string,
      c_lv_line     TYPE string,
      c_lv_filepath TYPE localfile,
      c_lv_query    TYPE aqs_quname.

*Field symbols
FIELD-SYMBOLS : <fs_record> TYPE ANY,
                <fs_comp> TYPE ANY.

*Get a Query name from the program
CALL FUNCTION 'RSAQ_DECODE_REPORT_NAME'
  EXPORTING
    reportname    = program
  IMPORTING
    query          = c_lv_query
  EXCEPTIONS
    no_query_report = 1
    OTHERS        = 2.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE ID sy-msgid TYPE sy-msgty NUMBER sy-msgno
          WITH sy-msgv1 sy-msgv2 sy-msgv3 sy-msgv4.
ENDIF.

*Select the filepath from ZBSD_T0246 table based
*on the query name and variant.
SELECT SINGLE filepath
  FROM zbsd_t0246
  INTO c_lv_filepath
  WHERE query = c_lv_query
  AND qvariant = syst-slset.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
*Open application server file.
  OPEN DATASET c_lv_filepath FOR OUTPUT IN TEXT MODE ENCODING DEFAULT.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    CLEAR c_lv_line.

*Create header of the file
    LOOP AT listdesc.
      CONCATENATE c_lv_line listdesc-fcol ';' INTO c_lv_line.
    ENDLOOP.
    TRANSFER c_lv_line TO c_lv_filepath.
    CLEAR c_lv_line.

*Transfer the data to the file
    LOOP AT datatab ASSIGNING <fs_record>.
      DO.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT sy-index OF STRUCTURE <fs_record> TO <fs_comp>.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
        c_lv_buf = <fs_comp>.
        IF sy-index = 1.
          c_lv_line = c_lv_buf.
        ELSE.
          CONCATENATE c_lv_line c_lv_buf INTO c_lv_line SEPARATED BY ';'.
        ENDIF.
        CLEAR c_lv_buf.
      ENDDO.
      TRANSFER c_lv_line TO c_lv_filepath.
      CLEAR c_lv_line.
    ENDLOOP.

*Close the file once the datas are transfered.
    CLOSE DATASET c_lv_filepath.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.

*File created in path &1
      MESSAGE s483(zbsd_0001) WITH c_lv_filepath.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
ELSE.

*File path not maintained in table ZBSD_T0246
  MESSAGE e484(zbsd_0001).
ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Foreign Key of MANDT
entry.content:
Let me try to explain with an example. In KNA1 which stores Customer General Data, you can see the field MANDT as a part of Primary Key. Here the Foreign Key relationship is KNA1-MANDT to TOOO-MANDT. This ensures that any customer record in KNA1 is tied to a valid client defined in T000.

Why it matters is if your SAP system has clients 100, 200, and 800, each client will have its own set of customer data in KNA1. The foreign key ensures that only valid client IDs (from T000) can be used when inserting or maintaining records in KNA1

entry.title: Re: SQ01 query with two info structures tables
entry.content: SAP standard info structures are upto S500. In your case, they are S911 & S961 and hence, it is custom developed one. It could be that one info structure would be used to capture sales order data while the other could be to capture delivery and billing data. Also, each info structure has its own update rules, defined during setup in MC24. These rules determine which fields are updated from which transactions like VA01, VL01N, VF01 etc.

entry.title: Time-based inspection points -S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello QM Expert,

Time-based inspection points are scheduled to repeat every 1 hour. In operation 0010, three inspection characteristics (MIC1, MIC2, and MIC3) are assigned. During the initial in-process inspection, all three characteristics should be included in the inspection lot. However, for subsequent time-based inspections, only one characteristic (MIC3) should be repeated, while the others should not be required. (Restricted to a single inspection characteristic).

Current System Behavior
In the standard setup of time-based inspection points (configured in the routing header and operation), all three inspection characteristics are repeated at every time interval. We also tested the approach of splitting into two separate operations, but it does not fulfill the requirement as intended.

 

Business Need
The requirement is to achieve this functionality within a single operation, so that:

  • Initial check = MIC1 , MIC2 & MIC3.
  • Subsequent hourly checks = only MIC3.

How  can we  achieve this in S/4HANA Public Cloud?

entry.title: Re: how to get the current week from calendar date
entry.content:
For information, WEEK() function only returns the calendar week, not the fiscal week, which is often different depending on the organization's fiscal year setup. To get the fiscal week, you need to reference SAP‚Äôs factory calendar or use custom logic based on your fiscal year variant. Of course, in SAP, fiscal weeks are not stored directly but you can derive from Fiscal Year Variants like K4 or V3.

May be you can consider to use Function Module DATE_TO_PERIOD_CONVERT which converts a calendar date into a fiscal period and fiscal year based on your company code and fiscal variant.

entry.title: Embedded Analytics - How to Analyze System/Browser/Network Performance ?
entry.content:
How to Analyze System Performance in Embedded Analytics ?

You can analyze your system performance using the Measurement Tool, or viewing a variety of stories that provide statistics and analysis.

 

To access the tool, from the side navigation, choose  System  -   Measurement Tool.

Client Test Score

The client test runs several scripts on the local machine and calculates a normalized score. Using current best practices, the client score can be categorized as follows:

  • Excellent: Score >= 75
  • Good: Score >= 50 and <75
  • Poor: Score < 50

Bandwidth measures the megabits per second (Mbps) transferred from server to client when downloading and uploading data. A higher bandwidth number is better than a lower number.

To improve your client score while keeping your existing hardware configuration, watch out for CPU intensive applications and processes that may have a negative impact on your SAP Analytics Cloud performance. For example:
  • Business video conferencing services
  • Virus scanning
  • Synchronizing shared network drives

Network Test Score

Latency is measured in milliseconds (ms). It describes the time it takes from the starting request until the response arrives. A good latency is a ping rate within a low milliseconds range.

The network score may be negatively affected by other applications consuming the bandwidth, various network configurations, or different network issues. For example:
  • Virtual Private Networks (VPN)
  • Firewalls
  • Corporate bandwidth
  • Internet bandwidth
  • Database performance (live data connections)
  • SAML IdP logon time

Optimize System Performance with the Analysis Tool

As an administrator of an SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can use the Performance Analysis Tool and the decision tree below to find resources that will help you resolve performance issues.

Who does this apply to?
  • Users with Read and Update permissions for System Information.
  • Admin and BI Admin standard application roles.

The following instructions apply primarily to SAP Analytics Cloud (public and private). Some sections may also be applicable to SAP Analytics Cloud, Embedded edition depending on feature availability.

Use the Performance Decision Tree

Follow the steps in the following decision tree to find resources that will help you to resolve performance issues.

This image is interactive. Hover over each area for a description. Click highlighted areas for more information.

 Guidance on Performance Testing

Caution

According to the General Terms and Conditions for SAP Cloud Services it is prohibited to perform any action on the cloud service which circumvents or endangers its operation or security.


Please note, performance testing might have a serious effect on private instances as well as on shared instances where the SAP Analytics Cloud tenant resides with multiple customer tenants on same instance. This is important because services being used on a certain system are shared among other customers. Due to that reason, performing stress or performance testing is only allowed on SAP Analytics Cloud Private Edition tenants.
  • When in doubt, reach out to your Account Team (Account Executive or Customer Success Professional) to clarify whether you are allowed to do the performance test or not.
  • Understand that the performance and specifications of non-production environments may not be the same as production environments. UAT performance testing cannot be performed on non-production systems.
  • As this is considered a support operation please notify SAP (through your Account Team) at least 15 business days in advance of the test so we can monitor the systems to avoid any outage.
Caution

A general stress test might create a load that could endanger the operation of the cloud service.

entry.title: Re: Dunning notices will not print
entry.content: If the master data and valid email are maintained but still you have the issue, then, probably, you should check Form template assignment in OPD. Even if OPD is set to email, SAP still needs a form template to generate the dunning notice. If the form is missing or inactive, the system cannot render the output. Please check in Output Parameter Determination ‚Üí Dunning whether a valid form template is linked and the form is active and released in SFP tcode

entry.title: Everify
entry.content:
Hi

For US, it‚Äôs a federal requirement for our Onboarding Admins to verify the work authorization for all new West employees. In cases where a reverification is needed for these documents, say in case of an immigrant visa, a ‚ÄúReverification‚Äù is required. This reverification can be triggered after months or even years after the start date of the new hire, depending on the expiry date of the current work authorization documents. These reverification requests are currently being routed to the Onboarding admin who originally processed their verification, and it causes an issue when that team member is now termed.

We are checking the feasibility of routing all these reverification requests to a super admin ID in Onboarding by default. The requests can then be triaged/ assigned to the active team members from the concerned site and this will ensure we don‚Äôt lose visibility to these reverification cases.

Thanks

Vijay

entry.title: Re: SAP Mail issues - tcode S000 - Locked user appearing...
entry.content: For information, transaction S000 pulls the data from table USR02 which contains all user master records. Having said that, by default, SAP does not filter out locked users in the internal user search within transaction S000. There is no standard configuration to restrict this. If you need this requirement desperately, may be you can go with screen enhancement or implicit enhancement in the search logic. Discuss with your ABAP team and see that the logic be to apply a filter on USR02-UFLAG = 0 to exclude locked users.

entry.title: Clarification on SAP Certification Exam Retake Policy
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,
I‚Äôm seeking clarification regarding the SAP certification exam retake policy. Specifically, I‚Äôve come across the following statement:
‚ÄúIn case an exam is not passed on the first try, please note that you can take the same exam up to three times. If you have failed an exam three times for the same version, you will have to wait until a new version is released. This limitation applies to all subscriptions you have purchased and is cross-checked. Each try counts as one attempt.‚Äù
Could someone please confirm if this is the official policy and point me to the source where this is documented (preferably on learning.sap.com or sap.com)?
Thank you in advance!
Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Clarification on SAP Certification Exam Retake Policy
entry.content: @Borivoje_Milosavljevic A candidate who fails an SAP Certification exam may retake it two more times (for a total of three attempts). Upon the third failure, the candidate must wait until the next version of the exam is available before attempting it again. This waiting period is typically several months. This rule is enforced across all exam delivery modes and exam types

entry.title: Re: Custom field in EPPM WBS structure
entry.content:
Hello @FranciscoCosta 

My apologies for the late reply,üòä

If you only see the Properties tab, it means you‚Äôre not working on a measure. In Custom Analytical Queries (CAQ), the Aggregation and Expression tabs are visible only for measures, not for characteristics.

How to activate Average.

  1. In Custom CDS Views, define an Analytical Cube based on your data source and include your numeric custom field as a measure, setting a default aggregation such as Sum, Max, or Min.
  2. Publish the cube, then add a Calculated Measure in Custom Analytical Queries and set Exception aggregation converted to average, using a reference characteristic such as Project/PROJ or Work. Breakdown Structure (WBS).

You also refer to the below-mentioned official SAP Documentation

  • SAP Help ‚Äì Custom Analytical Queries (features incl. calculated measures & exception aggregation). SAP Help Portal-Custom Analytical Queries and Services
  • SAP Help/Tutorial ‚Äì Building CAQ with Calculated Measures and Exception Aggregation. SAP-Create Custom Analytical Queries With Calculated Measures
  • SAP Help ‚Äì Create Analytical Cube in Custom CDS Views (make the field a measure first). SAP Help Portal-Creating a Cube
  • KBA 2544478 ‚Äì fields must have an aggregation in the CDS to be usable as measures in CAQ. SAP Support Portal-2544478 - Custom CDS View Fields Don't Appear in Custom Analytical Queries

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma
